heading.title: PART 10 REPRESENTATIVE PROCEEDINGS IN SUPREME COURT [ss 155–184]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 10 REPRESENTATIVE PROCEEDINGS IN SUPREME COURT [ss 155–184]
DIVISION 2 COMMENCEMENT OF REPRESENTATIVE PROCEEDINGS [ss 157–174]
[s 157] s 157 Commencement of representative proceedings

p.text: Subject to this Part, where:
7 or more persons have claims against the same person, and
the claims of all those persons are in respect of, or arise out of, the same, similar or related circumstances, and
the claims of all those persons give rise to a substantial common question of law or fact,
proceedings may be commenced by one or more of those persons as representing some or all of them.
Representative proceedings may be commenced:
whether or not the relief sought:
is, or includes, equitable relief, or
consists of, or includes, damages, or
includes claims for damages that would require individual assessment, or
is the same for each person represented, and
whether or not the proceedings:
are concerned with separate contracts or transactions between the defendant in the proceedings and individual group members, or
involve separate acts or omissions of the defendant done or omitted to be done in relation to individual group members.
See also UCPR Pt 6 Div 4 and Practice Note SC Gen 17 ss 3 and 4.

level.toc-caption: [s 157.10] Originating process for representative proceedings — formal requirements

heading.title: Originating process for representative proceedings — formal requirements

p.text: See CPA s 161 as to requirements for content of originating process.
Legislation cited in [s 157.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 164.

It is not necessary to show that the required number of represented persons have all asserted, or are even aware of, the postulated claims: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Giraffe World Australia Pty Ltd (1998) 84 FCR 512; 156 ALR 273; [1998] FCA 819; BC9803246 ; King v GIO Australia Holdings Ltd (2000) 100 FCR 209; 174 ALR 715; [2000] FCA 617; BC200002373 at [33] .

The word “claim” has an encompassing meaning. At its widest it includes any assertion of entitlement to a justiciable remedy: see Finance Sector Union of Australia v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1999) 94 FCR 179 at 187; 166 ALR 141; [1999] FCA 1250; BC9905739 ; and King v GIO Australia Holdings Ltd (2000) 100 FCR 209 at 221–223; 174 ALR 715; [2000] FCA 617; BC200002373 . It does not require satisfaction that a person has an accrued cause of action: King v AG Australia Holdings Ltd [2002] FCA 1560; BC200207682 at [10] per Moore J; Bray v F Hoffman-La Roche Ltd (2003) 130 FCR 317; 200 ALR 607; [2003] FCAFC 153; BC200303796 at [119] per Carr J.
Legislation cited in [s 157.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.19, r 6.19(1), r 6.19(1)(a).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 157, s 157(1), s 157(2).

The considerable permissive width of the present section is the result of a complicated history in the development of representation procedures. Previous provisions described the required relationship as one involving persons who had “the same interest or same liability” in the proceedings. This apparently simple “same interest” criterion had a varied history of liberality and restriction in its application: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd (1995) 182 CLR 398; 127 ALR 76 at 96; BC9506432 . It was at least accepted that the interest did not have to be proprietary. After the decision in Duke of Bedford v Ellis [1901] AC 1; [1900–3] All ER Rep 694; (1900) 83 LT 686; 70 LJ Ch 102 (representative order granted where produce growers claimed statutory rights to use premises at Covent Garden markets). However, some of the authorities tended to regard the rule as requiring something in the nature of a unity of interest and, in particular, as imposing a condition that all the persons to be represented had to have a common interest in the relief claimed in the proceedings. This view was based largely on the observations of Fletcher Moulton LJ in Markt & Co Ltd v Knight Steamship Co Ltd [1910] 2 KB 1021; (1910) 103 LT 369; 79 LJKB 939; 11 Asp MLC 460 .

The emphasis requiring the represented persons to have a common interest in the proceedings was partly a consequence of the Court of Chancery’s practices, where the representative procedure was used mainly (but not exclusively) as a practical means of avoiding the necessity of joining large numbers of known persons as formal parties to the proceedings. This origin reveals an analogy with the criteria for joinder of parties under rules such as UCPR r 6.19 . The joinder criteria include a requirement that all the rights to the relief claimed must arise out of the same “transaction or series of transactions”. That requirement is additional to the existence of some common question of fact or law: see generally [6.19.10]. Apart from the analogy with the joinder requirements, even the decision in Duke of Bedford v Ellis, above, itself may have played a part in the narrow use of the representative procedure: (see Esanda Finance Corp Ltd v Carnie (1992) 29 NSWLR 382 at 394; (1992) ASC 56-191 per Kirby P). This possibility arises because of the passage in the speech of Lord Macnaghten (AC at 8), where his Lordship said that in order to justify a representative action, it was necessary to establish: first, that all members of the alleged class had a common interest; second, that they all had a common grievance; and third, that the relief claimed was in its nature beneficial to them all. This passage, while not necessarily restrictive in its intended meaning, was apparently narrower than the actual words of the then current rules.

The current wording of CPA s 157(1) conclusively resolved an issue that had been much debated in the authorities dealing with the “same interest” requirement. This provision more explicitly refers to the similarity (rather than identity) of circumstances and questions. Similarly CPA s 157(2) makes it clear that the represented persons did not have to have a common interest in the actual relief claimed. These provisions are consistent with the authoritative judicial interpretation of the “same interest” criterion of the former wording: see [s 157.25]. At the same time, while the wording echoes the criteria for joinder of parties contained in UCPR r 6.19(1) , it explicitly uses a less restrictive criterion (than previous provisions) in describing the permissible relationship between the claims of the represented persons. Under CPA s 157 it is sufficient if the claims relevantly involve “the same, similar or related circumstances” — rather than that they involve “the same transaction or series of transactions” (see UCPR r 6.19(1)(a) ). This apparently closer alignment of the criteria for representation and joinder came after the decision in O'Sullivan v Challenger Managed Investments Ltd (2007) 214 FLR 1; [2007] NSWSC 383; BC200703448 ; where, under the former rules, the Supreme court refused to make a representation order even though the refusal was likely to result in the court acceding to a joinder application under UCPR r 6.19 : see O'Sullivan v Challenger Managed Investments Ltd, above, at [35]–[49], [55]–[57] and [66]–[73].
Legislation cited in [s 157.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 s 33C.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 157(1)(c).

The original, and apparently simple “same interest” criterion that governed the making of representative orders under earlier procedural rules had a varied history of liberality and restriction in its application. But the High Court authoritatively determined that a representation order could be made where there was some similarity of interest in the determination of a particular matter of law or fact: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd (1995) 182 CLR 398; 127 ALR 76; [1995] HCA 9; BC9506432 ; and Campbells Cash & Carry Pty Ltd v Fostif Pty Ltd (2006) 229 CLR 386 at 418–420, 450, 455–6; 229 ALR 58; [2006] HCA 41; BC200606677 (and see also Fostif Pty Ltd v Campbells Cash & Carry Pty Ltd (2005) 63 NSWLR 203 at 244–6; 218 ALR 166; [2005] NSWCA 83; BC200501667 ). The required similarity of interest could be established by the existence of some common ingredient in the causes of action potentially available: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd, above, at ALR 78; Prudential Assurance Co Ltd v Newman Industries Ltd [1981] Ch 229; [1979] 3 All ER 507; [1980] 2 WLR 339 . It could also be established by the existence of a significant question of fact, or law, that had a common relevance to the persons to be represented: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd, above, at ALR 78, 81, 91 and 97. It was certainly not necessary that all the persons represented share in the actual relief sought: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd, above, at ALR 81 (order invalidating agreements could operate to the disadvantage of some persons represented); Wong v Silkfield Pty Ltd (1999) 199 CLR 255; 15 ALR 373; [1999] HCA 48; BC9905665 (alleged misrepresentations made to multiple purchasers of lots in a multi storey development — likely different claims — representative action permitted under the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth) s 33C ).

CPA s 157(1)(c) expressly adopted this criterion of a similarity or commonality in relation to a substantial issue of fact or law. Satisfying that criterion involves identifying issues that are both common to the contemplated claims and substantial.

A “common question” is sufficient even if the group members have different “interests” in the practical outcome of the proceedings: Finance Sector Union of Australia v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1999) 94 FCR 179; 166 ALR 141; [1999] FCA 1250; BC9905739 (union claiming penalties and union members claiming award entitlements). Apprehended differences in the damages claimed by, or the evidence likely to be adduced in relation to, individual represented persons do not themselves preclude the existence of a substantial common question: Shipley v Masu Financial Management Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 252; BC200802113 at [38], [40] and [86]–[87] per Hammerschlag J citing Bright v Femcare Ltd (2002) 195 ALR 574; [2002] FCAFC 243; BC200204689 at [133]–[134] .

The term “substantial” refers to issues that are “real or of substance”: Wong v Silkfield, above, at [27] and following; Shipley v Masu Financial Management Pty Ltd, above at [37] and [83] per Hammerschlag J. The relevant issues have to be characterised by reference to the claims made in the pleadings, rather than by a prediction of the scope or effect of the likely evidence: Jameson v Professional Investment Services Pty Ltd (2009) 72 NSWLR 281; 253 ALR 515; [2009] NSWCA 28; BC200900948 at [52] .

The question of whether the representative procedure is potentially available ultimately comes down to a matter of practical judgment. A representative action is appropriate where, if the plaintiff wins, the persons purported to be represented also win: Shaw v Real Estate Board of Greater Vancouver (1973) 36 DLR (3d) 250 at 254 (a passage that was approved by Toohey and Gaudron JJ in Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd, above, at ALR 89). This impressionistic criterion must be understood as referring to the hypothesised common issue — rather than to the ultimate result of the proceedings: see Fostif Pty Ltd v Campbells Cash & Carry Pty Ltd, above NSWLR at 242–3.
CPA s 157(2) resolves what had been a continuing controversy as to whether a representative order could be made where the persons to be represented had different individual damages claims.

Based on the observations of Fletcher Moulton LJ in Markt & Co Ltd v Knight Steamship Co Ltd [1910] 2 KB 1021; (1910) 103 LT 369; 79 LJKB 939; 11 Asp MLC 460 , various cases held that representative orders were not available unless the proceedings involved some element of common interest, beyond the mere coincidence of issues for determination. An outcome of this approach was that representation orders were thought to be inappropriate if the proceedings involved different claims for damages: Mercantile Marine Service Assn v Toms [1916] 2 KB 243 ; Hardie and Lane Ltd v Chiltern [1928] 1 KB 663 at 687 (no representation order for claims for damages in tort); Smith v Cardiff Corp [1954] 1 QB 210 at 220 (representative order refused to housing estate tenants): O'Sullivan v Challenger Managed Investments Ltd (2007) 214 FLR 1; [2007] NSWSC 383; BC200703448 at [41]–[48] .

The perceived restriction was sometimes, and increasingly, either ignored or expressly rejected: Wood v McCarthy [1893] 1 QB 775 (action against union membership); EMI Records Ltd v Riley [1981] 2 All ER 838; [1981] 1 WLR 923 (representative claim for damages for breach of copyright). Ultimately, and even before Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd (1995) 182 CLR 398; 127 ALR 76; [1995] HCA 9; BC9506432 , it was accepted that claims for damages were not automatically excluded from the operation of the representative procedures merely because they were made severally by numerous plaintiffs or because they were resisted by numerous defendants: Prudential Assurance Co Ltd v Newman Industries [1981] Ch 229; [1979] 3 All ER 507; [1980] 2 WLR 339 ; Irish Shipping Ltd v Commercial Union Assurance Co Plc [1991] 2 QB 206; [1989] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 144 . The permissibility of a representative order in these circumstances was apparently endorsed in Campbells Cash & Carry Pty Ltd v Fostif Pty Ltd (2006) 229 CLR 386 at [50]; 229 ALR 58; [2006] HCA 41; BC200606677 .

In addition, the practical significance of this perceived restriction was diminished by the use of declaratory and injunction proceedings to deal with liability-related issues: Jones v Cory Bros & Co Ltd (1921) 56 L Jo 302 (declaration for breach of statutory duty by a colliery owner); Bollinger v Costa Brava Wine Co Ltd (No 2) [1961] 1 All ER 561; [1961] 1 WLR 277; [1961] RPC 116 ; HP Bulmer Ltd v J Bollinger SA [1977] 2 CMLR 625; [1978] RPC 79 ; Prudential Assurance Co Ltd v Newman Industries Ltd [1981] Ch 229; [1979] 3 All ER 507; [1980] 2 WLR 339 ; O'Sullivan v Challenger Managed Investments Ltd, above BC200703448 at [58]–[61].

level.toc-caption: [s 157.40] Claims for injunctive or declaratory relief

heading.title: Claims for injunctive or declaratory relief

p.text: This resolves some debate in the authorities as to whether claims of this nature, made purportedly on behalf of numerous persons, amount to a single claim for the same relief: see Allphones Retail Pty Ltd v Weimann [2009] FCAFC 135; BC200908921 at [82]–[89] (declarations properly sought on behalf of group members); Bray v F Hoffman-La Roche Ltd (2003) 130 FCR 317; 200 ALR 607; [2003] FCAFC 153; BC200303796 : see especially per Branson J at [210], compare with Carr J at [121].

The use of the representative procedure finds a particular application in proceedings by, or against, unincorporated associations. It has long been recognised that problems can arise in relation to such proceedings, where there is no specific procedure for representation: see Ex parte Goddard; Re Falvey (1946) 46 SR (NSW) 289 ; Carlton Cricket and Football Club v Joseph [1970] VR 487 ; Amey v Fifer [1971] 1 NSWLR 685 ; Maritime Services Board of New South Wales v Australian Chamber of Shipping [1977] 1 NSWLR 648 ; compare Peckham v Moore [1975] 1 NSWLR 353 . The present section permits representative proceedings against the association: Wood v McCarthy [1893] 1 QB 775 (action against union membership); Taff Vale Railway Co v Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants [1901] AC 426 at 438 (action against union membership). It cannot be used to select one or more members of an unincorporated association and sue them instead of the association as a whole: London Assn for Protection of Trade v Greenlands Ltd [1916] 2 AC 15; [1916–17] All ER Rep 452 ; Healey v Ballarat East Bowling Club [1961] VR 206 . In exceptional cases, proceedings in which the unincorporated association is the nominal plaintiff may be regarded as regular if the pleading in fact discloses the identity of the members of the association and the fact that they are the moving persons in the proceedings: Papaellinas v Mossop (NSWCA, Priestley, Clarke and Meagher JJA, 29 July 1994, unreported, BC9402846); Lee v Surry Hills Mutual Loan Club [2007] NSWSC 650; BC200705046 . If proceedings are wrongly commenced in the name of the unincorporated association, the irregularity can be corrected by amendment: M & M Civil Engineering Pty Ltd v Sunshine Coast Turf Club [1987] 2 Qd R 401 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 158] s 158 Standing

p.text: For the purposes of section 157(1)(a) , a person has a sufficient interest to commence representative proceedings against another person on behalf of other persons if the person has standing to commence proceedings on the person’s own behalf against that other person.

The person may commence representative proceedings on behalf of other persons against more than one defendant irrespective of whether or not the person and each of those persons have a claim against every defendant in the proceedings.
If a person has commenced representative proceedings, that person retains standing:
to continue the proceedings, and
to bring an appeal from a judgment in the proceedings,
even though the person ceases to have a claim against any defendant.
Legislation cited in [s 158.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 Pt IVA.

Section 158(2) provides that representative proceedings may be taken against several defendants even if not all group members have a claim against all defendants. The provision resolves the apparently conflicting views expressed in the Federal Court about the operation of Pt IVA of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth): see Philip Morris (Australia) Ltd v Nixon [2000] 170 ALR 487; [2000] FCA 229; BC200000845 (diversity of defendants impermissible); and compare Bray v F Hoffman-La Roche Ltd (2003) 130 FCR 317; 200 ALR 607; [2003] FCAFC 153; BC200303796 ; McBride v Monzie Pty Ltd (2007) 164 FCR 559; 244 ALR 463; [2007] FCA 1947; BC200710711 at [4]–[7] per Finkelstein J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 159] s 159 Is consent required to be a group member?

leg:heading.title: Is consent required to be a group member?

p.text: Subject to subsection (2) , the consent of a person to be a group member is not required.
None of the following is a group member in representative proceedings unless the person gives consent in writing to being so:
the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory,
a Minister of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory,
a body corporate established for a public purpose by a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, other than an incorporated company or association,
an officer of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, in his or her capacity as an officer.

level.toc-caption: [s 159.5] Judicial officers in the represented group

heading.title: Judicial officers in the represented group

p.text: It may be appropriate to exclude particular judicial officers from the represented group in some circumstances: see for instance Johnson Tiles Pty Ltd v Esso Australia Ltd (2000) 104 FCR 564; (2001) ATPR ¶41-794; [2000] FCA 1572; BC200006717 at [16] . Even if a judicial officer has been excluded from the represented group, their potential interest in the subject matter and outcome of the proceedings may preclude their involvement in the management and determination of the proceedings: Kirby v Centro Properties Ltd (No 2) (2008) 172 FCR 376; 252 ALR 557; [2008] FCA 1657; BC200810033 at [13] , [23].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 160] s 160 Persons under legal incapacity

p.text: It is not necessary for a person under legal incapacity to have a tutor merely in order to be a group member.
A group member who is a person under legal incapacity may only take a step in representative proceedings, or conduct part of the proceedings, by the member’s tutor.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 161] s 161 Originating process

p.text: The originating process in representative proceedings, or a document filed in support of the originating process, must, in addition to any other matters required to be included:
describe or otherwise identify the group members to whom the proceedings relate, and
specify the nature of the claims made on behalf of the group members and the relief claimed, and
specify the question of law or facts common to the claims of the group members.
In describing or otherwise identifying group members for the purposes of subsection (1) , it is not necessary to name, or specify the number of, the group members.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 162] s 162 Right of group member to opt out

leg:heading.title: Right of group member to opt out

p.text: The Court must fix a date before which a group member may opt out of representative proceedings in the Court.
A group member may opt out of the representative proceedings by written notice given under the local rules before the date so fixed.

The Court may, on application by a group member, the representative party or the defendant in the proceedings, fix another date so as to extend the period during which a group member may opt out of the representative proceedings.
Except with the leave of the Court, the hearing of representative proceedings must not commence earlier than the date before which a group member may opt out of the proceedings.
Legislation cited in [s 162.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 180(5).

Even though the court may be satisfied that the representative proceedings are appropriate, group members must be given notice of the proceedings. They have a time limited entitlement to “opt out” of the proceedings. The entitlement is exercised by giving written notice complying with UCPR Pt 58: see also Practice Note SC Gen 17 para 5.6. UCPR Form 115 is the relevant form.
The “opt out” procedure does not apply to appeals in representative proceedings: see CPA s 180(5) .

The “opt out” procedure under the present section resolves previous judicial debate about the comparative desirability of the “opt in” and “opt out” procedures: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd (1995) 182 CLR 398; 127 ALR 76; [1995] HCA 9; BC9506432 ; Jameson v Professional Investment Services Pty Ltd (2009) 72 NSWLR 281; 253 ALR 515; [2009] NSWCA 28; BC200900948 at [44]–[47] , [98]–[121] approving Multiplex Funds Management Ltd v P Dawson Nominees Pty Ltd (2007) 164 FCR 275; 244 ALR 600; [2007] FCAFC 200; BC200711295 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 163] s 163 Causes of action accruing after commencement of representative proceedings

leg:heading.title: Causes of action accruing after commencement of representative proceedings

p.text: The Court may at any stage of representative proceedings, on application by the representative party, give leave to amend the originating process commencing the representative proceedings so as to alter the description of the group.
The description of the group may be altered so as to include a person:
whose cause of action accrued after the commencement of the representative proceedings but before such date as the Court fixes when giving leave, and
who would have been included in the group, or, with the consent of the person would have been included in the group, if the cause of action had accrued before the commencement of the proceedings.
The date fixed under subsection (2)(a) may be the date on which leave is given or another date before or after that date.

If the Court gives leave under subsection (1) , it may also make any other orders it thinks just, including an order relating to the giving of notice to persons who, as a result of the amendment, will be included in the group and the date before which such persons may opt out of the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 164] s 164 Situation where fewer than 7 group members

leg:heading.title: Situation where fewer than 7 group members

p.text: If, at any stage of representative proceedings, it appears likely to the Court that there are fewer than 7 group members, the Court may, on such conditions (if any) as it thinks fit:
order that the proceedings continue under this Part, or
order that the proceedings no longer continue under this Part.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 165] s 165 Distribution costs excessive

p.text: If:
the relief claimed in representative proceedings is or includes payment of money to group members (otherwise than in respect of costs), and

on application by the defendant, the Court concludes that it is likely that, if judgment were to be given in favour of the representative party, the cost to the defendant of identifying the group members and distributing to them the amounts ordered to be paid to them would be excessive having regard to the likely total of those amounts,
the Court may, by order:
direct that the proceedings no longer continue under this Part, or
stay the proceedings so far as it relates to relief of the kind mentioned in paragraph (a) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 166] s 166 Court may order discontinuance of proceedings in certain circumstances

leg:heading.title: Court may order discontinuance of proceedings in certain circumstances

p.text: The Court may, on application by the defendant or of its own motion, order that proceedings no longer continue under this Part if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so because:

the costs that would be incurred if the proceedings were to continue as representative proceedings are likely to exceed the costs that would be incurred if each group member conducted a separate proceeding, or
all the relief sought can be obtained by means of proceedings other than representative proceedings under this Part, or
the representative proceedings will not provide an efficient and effective means of dealing with the claims of group members, or
a representative party is not able to adequately represent the interests of the group members, or
it is otherwise inappropriate that the claims be pursued by means of representative proceedings.

It is not, for the purposes of subsection (1)(e) , inappropriate for claims to be pursued by means of representative proceedings merely because the persons identified as group members in relation to the proceedings:
do not include all persons on whose behalf those proceedings might have been brought, or
are aggregated together for a particular purpose such as a litigation funding arrangement.
If the Court dismisses an application under this section, the Court may order that no further application under this section be made by the defendant except with the leave of the Court.
Leave for the purposes of subsection (3) may be granted subject to such conditions as to costs as the Court considers just.
Legislation cited in [s 166.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 Pt IVA.

Even where the basic preconditions for representative proceedings have been met, the court retains a discretion to direct that the proceedings not be continued as representative proceedings. The factors relevant to the exercise of the discretion include:
the comparative cost and suitability of representative proceedings: see CPA s 166(1)(a) and (c)
the nature of the relief: see CPA s 166(1)(b)
the suitability of the representative: see CPA s 166(1)(d)

the description of the group or class; the procedures for notification to group members; the procedures for settlement of the proceedings: see CPA s 166(1)(e) : Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd (1995) 182 CLR 398; 127 ALR 76 at 79, 83 and 97; [1995] HCA 9; BC9506432 and

CPA s 166(2) specifically contemplates representative proceedings being brought on behalf of a limited group of identified individuals. This reflects the view taken in Multiplex Funds Management Ltd v Dawson Nominees Pty Ltd (2007) 164 FCR 275; 244 ALR 600; [2007] FCAFC 200; BC200711295 , under Pt IVA of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth). Nevertheless, if the class of represented persons is too narrowly defined (by only including a subclass of the persons actually interested) that may itself afford a basis for refusing to permit the action to continue: Jameson v Professional Investment Services Pty Ltd (2009) 72 NSWLR 281; 253 ALR 515; [2009] NSWCA 28; BC200900948 at [122]–[124] .

The potentially differing interests of the represented persons in the ultimate outcome of the proceedings, and the nature and scope of the different issues necessary to determine their individual claims are clearly relevant to the continuation of the proceedings: Wong v Silkfield Pty Ltd (1999) 199 CLR 255; 165 ALR 373; [1999] HCA 48; BC9905665 (likely different damages claims). However, if the court is satisfied of the existence of substantial common issues, the rules obviously intend that other issues in the proceedings will be the subject of specific directions under CPA ss 168–170 .

The competence of the representative party is clearly a relevant consideration: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd (1995) 182 CLR 398; 127 ALR 76 at 81; [1995] HCA 9; BC9506432 per Brennan J (“the self-proclaimed carrier of a litigious banner may prove to be an indolent or incompetent champion … in the courtroom”). Similarly, the representative party’s willingness to comply with any directions relating to the conduct of the proceedings is also a relevant consideration to the exercise of the discretion: Carnie v Esanda Finance Corporation Ltd (1996) 38 NSWLR 465; (1996) ASC ¶56-336; BC9501803 (the plaintiff was ultimately unwilling to bear the cost of the “opt in” procedure proposed and the proceedings did not proceed on a representative basis).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 167] s 167 Effect of discontinuance order under this Part

leg:heading.title: Effect of discontinuance order under this Part

p.text: If the Court makes an order under section 164 , 165 or 166 that proceedings no longer continue under this Part:
the proceedings may be continued as proceedings by the representative party on the party’s own behalf against the defendant, and
on the application of a person who was a group member for the purposes of the proceedings, the Court may order that the person be joined as an applicant in the proceedings.
In this section:
, in relation to proceedings, includes a claimant or plaintiff (as the case may be) in the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 168] s 168 Determination of questions where not all common

leg:heading.title: Determination of questions where not all common

p.text: If it appears to the Court that determination of the question or questions common to all group members will not finally determine the claims of all group members, the Court may give directions in relation to the determination of the remaining questions.

In the case of questions common to the claims of some only of the group members, the directions given by the Court may include directions establishing a sub-group consisting of those group members and appointing a person to be the sub-group representative party on behalf of the sub-group members.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 169] s 169 Individual questions

p.text: In giving directions under section 168 , the Court may permit an individual group member to appear in the proceedings for the purpose of determining a question that relates only to the claims of that member.
In such a case, the individual group member, and not the representative party, is liable for costs associated with the determination of the question.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 170] s 170 Directions relating to commencement of further proceedings

leg:heading.title: Directions relating to commencement of further proceedings

p.text: If a question cannot properly or conveniently be dealt with by the Court under section 168 or 169 , the Court may give directions for the commencement and conduct of other proceedings, whether or not group proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 171] s 171 Adequacy of representation

p.text: If, on application by a group member, it appears to the Court that a representative party is not able adequately to represent the interests of the group members, the Court may substitute another group member as representative party and make such other orders as it thinks fit.

If, on application by a sub-group member, it appears to the Court that a sub-group representative party is not able adequately to represent the interests of the sub-group members, the Court may substitute another person as sub-group representative party and may make such other orders as it thinks fit.

There is a clear power to substitute a representative plaintiff where the representative plaintiff is not able to represent the interests of the represented parties: Tongue v Tamworth City Council (2004) 141 FCR 233; [2004] FCA 1702; BC200408933 (a representative plaintiff who was ill was substituted).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 172] s 172 Stay of execution in certain circumstances

leg:heading.title: Stay of execution in certain circumstances

p.text: If a defendant in representative proceedings commences proceedings in the Court against a group member, the Court may order a stay of execution in respect of any relief awarded to the group member in the representative proceedings until the other proceedings are determined.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 173] s 173 Approval of Court required for settlement and discontinuance

leg:heading.title: Approval of Court required for settlement and discontinuance

p.text: Representative proceedings may not be settled or discontinued without the approval of the Court.
If the Court gives such approval, it may make such orders as are just with respect to the distribution of any money, including interest, paid under a settlement or paid into the Court.

Court approval is required for any settlement, whether it involves global settlement of all group members' claims: McMullin v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd (No 6) (1998) 84 FCR 1; 156 ALR 257; BC9803267 partial settlement of the claims against an individual respondent, or settlement of all claims against a particular respondent: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Chats House Investments Pty Ltd (1996) 71 FCR 250; 142 ALR 177; 22 ACSR 539; BC9606509 ; Bray v F Hoffman-La Roche Ltd [2003] FCA 1505; BC200307923 at [22]–[24] .

In King v AG Australia Holdings Ltd (2002) 121 FCR 480; 191 ALR 697; [2002] FCA 872; BC200203825 the parties agreed, and the court held, that settlements negotiated directly between a respondent and group members did not require approval.
Legislation cited in [s 173.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 173, 175, s 176.

Representative parties will typically be required to give group members notice of the terms of any proposed settlement or discontinuance of the proceedings: CPA ss 173 and 175 . Prior court approval is required for any such notice: see CPA s 176 . An application for approval is made by notice of motion. The application may simultaneously seek approval for the form of any notice to group members and approval of the proposed settlement or discontinuance itself: Dorajay Pty Ltd v Aristocrat Leisure Ltd (2008) 67 ACSR 569; [2008] FCA 1311; BC200807523 at [4]–[9] per Stone J.

The application for approval must be supported by an affidavit, generally from the legal practitioner with the carriage of the matter on behalf of the representative party. The affidavit should provide evidence addressing the criteria referred to in [s 173.15]. Any evidence about the group members apparent prospects of success, and the apparent risks and costs involved in the proceedings, is potentially prejudicial to the interests of the represented party. An appropriate practice is for evidence dealing with these matters to be filed in a separate, closed envelope and for the notice of motion to include provision for an order that the opinion be confidential, not be required to be served, and be kept on the court file in a sealed envelope marked “Not to be opened without leave of a Justice of the Court”: Darwalla Milling Co Pty Ltd v F Hoffman-La Roche (No 2) (2006) 236 ALR 322; (2007) ATPR ¶42-134; [2006] FCA 1388; BC200608652 .

level.toc-caption: [s 173.15] Approval for settlement or discontinuance of representative proceedings

heading.title: Approval for settlement or discontinuance of representative proceedings

p.text: Where court approval is sought the principal question is whether the proposed settlement is a fair and reasonable compromise of the claims of the group members: Lopez v Star World Enterprises Pty Ltd (1999) ATPR ¶41-678; [1999] FCA 104; BC9900314 per Finkelstein J. The representative party, and their legal representatives have a particular responsibility to satisfy the court that the proposed compromise is in the interests of the group members, and discharging that responsibility may not always be coincident with the individual interests of the representative party.
The considerations relevant to the court’s approval decision will at least include the following:
The complexity of the issues and the stage and duration of the proceedings: Williams v FAI Home Security Pty Ltd (No 4) (2000) 180 ALR 459; [2000] FCA 1925; BC200008064 at [31] .
The reaction of the class to the settlement.
The apparent degree of risk of favourable resolution of the contentious issues, both as to liability and damages.
The likely actual recoverability of any damages that might be awarded.

The apparent reasonableness of the proposal, having regard to the risks of favourable resolution of the issues and the risks of actual recovery: Darwalla Milling Co Pty Ltd v F Hoffman-La Roche (No 2) (2006) 236 ALR 322; (2007) ATPR ¶42-134; [2006] FCA 1388; BC200608652 per Jessup J.

The nature of the group membership, the nature of any amendment proposed by the settlement terms, and the potential impact of the proposal on other potentially entitled persons: Williams v FAI Home Security Pty Ltd (No 4) (2000) 180 ALR 459; [2000] FCA 1925; BC200008064 at [31]–[35] and [45] if the proposed settlement involves narrowing the scope of the group membership, that consideration will itself be likely to require prior notice to the potentially affected persons).

The nature and extent of any different levels of compensation proposed for particular categories of group members: Courtney v Medtel Pty Ltd (No 5) (2004) 212 ALR 311; [2004] FCA 1406; BC200407227 per Sackville J.

(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 177(3).

Court approval of the representative proceedings in not conditioned upon satisfaction about the assessment of the claims of individual group members: see CPA s 177(3) . Nonetheless, the potential entitlement of individual members, and the apparent adequacy of the means for their assessment and satisfaction, will be significant considerations in the determination of any application for approval: see Lopez v Star World Enterprises Pty Ltd (1999) ATPR ¶41-678; Brian McMullin v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd (No 6) (FCA, Wilcox J, NG 305/95, 27 November 1997, unreported, BC9707043). The decision in Darwalla Milling Co Pty Ltd v F Hoffman-La Roche (No 2) (2006) 236 ALR 322; (2007) ATPR ¶42-134; [2006] FCA 1388; BC200608652 deals with both the approval of the lump sum settlement itself (at [45]–[55]), and the scheme for assessment of individual claims and distribution of the settlement amount to the group members (at [57]–[66]).

level.toc-caption: [s 173.25] Approval of settlement sum for legal cost

heading.title: Approval of settlement sum for legal cost

p.text: Where a proposed settlement includes provision for payment of a legal costs the court can require evidence of their reasonableness: Williams v FAI Home Security Pty Ltd (No 4) (2000) 180 ALR 459; [2000] FCA 1925; BC200008064 at [47] . That evidence may be provided by the applicant’s solicitors: Darwalla Milling Co Pty Ltd v F Hoffman-La Roche (No 2) (2006) 236 ALR 322; (2007) ATPR ¶42-134; [2006] FCA 1388; BC200608652 at [97]–[102] ($30.5 million settlement amount including $10.5 million costs). The costs evidence may be required to be supported by independent corroboration (that they have been correctly calculated in accordance with any fee agreement and appear to have been reasonably incurred and proportionate to the proceedings): Courtney v Medtel Pty Ltd (No 5) (2004) 212 ALR 311; [2004] FCA 1406; BC200407227 at [61] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 174] s 174 Settlement of individual claim of representative party

leg:heading.title: Settlement of individual claim of representative party

p.text: A representative party may, with the leave of the Court, settle the party’s individual claim in whole or in part at any stage of the representative proceedings.
A representative party who is seeking leave to settle, or who has settled, the party’s individual claim may, with the leave of the Court, withdraw as representative party.

If a person has sought leave to withdraw as representative party under subsection (2) , the Court may, on application by a group member, make an order for the substitution of another group member as representative party and may make such other orders as it thinks fit.
Before granting a person leave to withdraw as a representative party:

the Court must be satisfied that notice of the application has been given to group members in accordance with section 175(1) and in sufficient time for them to apply to have another person substituted as the representative party, and
any application for the substitution of another group member as a representative party must have been determined.

level.toc-caption: [s 174.5] Granting of leave to a representative plaintiff

heading.title: Granting of leave to a representative plaintiff

p.text: The Supreme Court is empowered to grant leave to a representative plaintiff who is seeking leave to settle or who has settled, to withdraw and be substituted by another member of the represented group: see Oasis Fund Management Ltd v Royal Bank of Scotland NV [2010] NSWSC 584; BC201004206 at [26].
